awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Gender and Diversity Analysis in Research across the Science Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Integrating into research design and analysis new perspectives on the ways in which biological and social categories intersect and overlap has led to discovery and innovation across numerous disciplines. It also promotes rigorous, reproducible and responsible science and technology. For example, car safety systems were dramatically improved to increase injury protection for women after national car crash data were separated for male and female drivers and female car crash dummies were introduced to account for the effect of acceleration on sex-specific biomechanics. To reap the benefits of the perspectives this approach offers in science and engineering research, it is essential that three pillars of academic research infrastructure coordinate efforts. This project brings together researchers and administrators at universities, journal editors, and funding agencies in two international workshops.  The pair of workshops will share perspectives and resources across the U.S. and Canadian communities with the aim of fostering iSGDA in computer science and engineering research.  

Much progress has been made recently incorporating intersectional sex, gender, and diversity analysis (iSGDA) into medicine, health, and life science research.  The workshops will draw from those models where relevant and focus on fields that are lagging behind.  Attendees will include researchers from all areas of computer science and engineering, including artificial intelligence, machine learning, robotics, natural language processing, mechanical, civil, and other engineering. The long-term goals of the workshops are to: conceptualize methodologies for integrating iSGDA into research design, processes, analysis, and interpretation of research results; disseminate methods to researchers and staff across research institutions, funding agencies, and peer-reviewed journals; train the current and next generation of researchers who serve as peer reviewers for funding agencies, journals, and hiring, tenure, and promotion committees, and train faculty on best practices for incorporating these methods into core courses in their disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to convene participants from the United States and Canada to understand how to foster Inclusion and Intersectionality in engineering and computer science research. The outcomes of the workshops resulted in 1) providing advice to NSF and NSERC on how to foster intersectional research; 2) building community among academic researchers and across scientific enterprise; 3) identifying tools and best practices for researchers in engineering and computer science disciplines that can be used to integrate intersectional research analysis into their research; 4) establishing strategies for presenting information to peer-review evaluators both within funding agencies and at academic journals; and 5) developing recommendations for next steps, including policy recommendations for NSF and NSERC.

Throughout the workshop series, a diverse range of researchers provided practical and theoretical research models for fostering Inclusion and Intersectionality. Participants for all workshops came from: 1) demographically diverse backgrounds; 2) a diverse set of disciplines (humanists, social scientists, computer scientists, various engineering disciplines, communications, etc.); and 3) key sectors of the scientific community (funding agencies, journals editors, universities, professional societies, etc.). Group activities and case study activities provided the opportunities for participants to apply these methods to their own work through discussion and problem solving. The workshops also focused on providing researchers, administrators, journal editors and reviewers, and funders the opportunity to learn more about best practices and identify tools to foster the incorporation of intersectional research in engineering and computer science disciplines. 

As a result of the workshops, we recommend that three pillars of the science infrastructure funding agencies, universities and research institutions, peer-reviewed journals—coordinate efforts to implement Inclusive and Intersectional Research and Experimental Design in coordinated top/down and bottom/up approaches. 

Funding agencies should ask applicants, where appropriate, to explain how inclusive and intersectional analysis is relevant to their proposed research. Funding agencies can support these efforts by providing calls for proposals in this area to further our understanding with empirical data performed by social scientists. We recommend that NSF develop policy on inclusive research and design-as part of Intellectual Merit. This follows well established policy by the European Commission and the German Research Foundation (DFG), both of which include this aspect under their "excellence" criteria. NSERC is well on its way to providing robust policy in this area and is integrating some of the workshop findings into policy. In July 2021, a guidance document was posted on the NSERC website (https://www.nserc-crsng.gc.ca/NSERC-CRSNG/Policies-Politiques/EDI guidanceConseils EDI eng.asp).

Universities and research institutions need to step up to incorporate conceptual tools for inclusive and intersectional analysis into the core curriculum of computer science and engineering in order to prepare the scientific workforce for the future. Harvard University-in response to student demand-integrated issues surrounding race and gender and how this play out in algorithms and systems into the core computer science curriculum. Stanford University and the Technical University of Munich have also followed suit. To our knowledge, most Colleges/Schools of Engineering, in the US and Canada, have not integrated intersectional analysis into core courses.

Editorial boards of peer-reviewed journals should require sophisticated inclusive and intersectional analysis when selecting papers for publication to ensure high quality research. The uptake of such guidelines in health and medicine has been swift. Outside of medical journals, Nature adopted the SAGER guidelines, an internationally recognized tool for sex and gender equity in research design, in 2020. This tool can be expanded to include inclusive and intersectional research.

The key outcomes of the workshops were an increased understanding of importance of including Inclusion and Intersectionality in research and analysis; identification of tools for researchers to effectively integrate Inclusive and Intersectional analysis into their research; the formation of a community of scholars interested in or who currently practice Inclusive and Intersectional analysis; and the development of three cases to serve as examples. The cases are focused on Domestic Robots, Sustainable Fashion, and Computer Science curricula. The case studies will live on the Gendered Innovations website, hosted by Stanford University (http://genderedinnovations.stanford.edu/what-is-gendered-innovations.html).
